div.p: A COMEDIE, As it hath beene Presented with good Applause at the private house in Drurie Lane, by her Majesties Servants.

Written by
Francis Beamount,
and John Flecher.
Gent.
LONDON Printed by Thomas Cotes, for Andrew Crooke, and William Cooke. 1639.

list.item: VAllentine, a Gallant that will not bee perswaded to keepe his estate.
A Merchant, friend to Master Lovegood.
Fountaine, companions of Vallentine, and sutors to the Widdow.
Bellamore, companions of Vallentine, and sutors to the Widdow.
Harebraine, companions of Vallentine, and sutors to the Widdow.
Lance a Faulkoner, and an ancient servant to Vallentines Father.
Shorthose the clowne, & servant to the Widdow
Roger, Ralph, & Humphrey, three servants to the Widdow.
Luce a waiting Gentlewoman to the Widdow.

sp.speaker: Merchant.
sp.p: WHen saw you Ʋallentine.

sp.speaker: Ʋncle.
sp.p: Not since the Horserace, he's taken up with those that wooe the Widdow.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: How can he live by snatches from such people, he bore a worthy minde.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Alas, he's sunke, his meanes are gone, he wants, and which is worse,
Takes a delight in doing so.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Thats strange.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Runs Lunaticke, if you but talk of states, he cannot be brought now he has spent his owne, to thinke theres inheritance, or meanes, but all a common riches, all men bound to be his Bailiffes:

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: This is something dangerous.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p:
No Gent. that has estate to use, it in keeping house, or followers, for those wayes he cries against, for eating sins, dull surfets, cramming of serving men, mustering of beggers, maintaine hospitals for Kites, and curs, grounding their fat faithes upon old Countrey proverbes, God blesse the founders; these
he would have vented into more manly uses, Wit and carriage, and never thinkes of state, or meanes, the ground workes: holding it monstrous, men should feed their bodies, and starve their understandings.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Thats most certaine.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Yes, if he could stay there.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why let him marry, and that way rise againe.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Its most impossible, he will not looke with any hansomenesse upon a woman.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Is he so strange to women.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: I know not what it is, a foolish glory he has got, I know not where, to balke those benefits, and yet he will converse and flatter um, make um, or faire, or foule, rugged, or smooth, as his impression serves, for he affirmes, they are onely lumps, and undigested peeces, lickt over to a forme, by our affections, and then they show; The lovers let um passe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: He might be one, he carries as much promise; they are wondrous merry.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: O their hopes are high sir.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.p: Is Vallentine come to Towne.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Last night I heard.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: We misse him monstrously in our directions, for this Widdow, is as stately, and as crafty, and stands I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Haire.
sp.p: Let her stand sure, she falls before us else, come lets goe seeke Vallentine.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: This Widdow seemes a gallant:

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: A goodly woman, and to her hansomnesse she beares her state, reserved, and great Fortune has made her Mistresse of a full meanes, and well she knowes to use it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I would Ʋallentine had her.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Theres no hope of that Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: A that condition, he had his morgage in againe.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: I would he had.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Seeke meanes, and see what Ile doe, however let the money be paid in, I never sought a Gentlemans undoing, nor eate the bread of other mens vexations, the morgage shall be rendred backe, take time fort, you told me of another brother:

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Yes sir, more miserable then he, for he has eate him, and drunke him up, a handsome Gentleman, and a fine Scholler.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: What are these?

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: The tennants, th'ie doe what they can,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: It is well prepared, be earnest honest friends and loud upon him, he is deafe to his owne good.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: We meane to tell him part of our mindes ant please you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Doe, and doe it home, and in what my care may helpe, or my perswasions when we meete next.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Doe but perswade him fairely; and for your money, mine, and these mens thankes too, and what we can be able:

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yare most honest, you shall finde me no lesse, and so I leave you, prosper your businesse my friends. Exit Merchant

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Pray heaven it may sir:

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Nay if hee will be mad, Ile be mad with him, and tell him that Ile not spare him, his Father kept good meate, good drinke, good fellowes, good hawkes, good hounds, and bid his neighbours welcome; kept him too, and supplyed his prodigality, yet kept his state still, must wee turne Tennants now, after we have lived under the race of Gentry, and maintaind good yeomantry, to some of the City, to a great shoulder of Mutton, and a Custard, and have our state turned into Cabbidge Gardens, must it be so:

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: You must be milder to him.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Thats as he makes his game:

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Intreate him lovingly, and make him feele:

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Ile pinch him to the bones else.

sp.speaker: Vallen.
sp.p: Within. And tell the Gentleman, Ile be with him presently, say I want money too, I must not faile boy.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Youle want clothes, I hope.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: Bid the young Courtier repaire to me anon, Ile reade to him.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: He comes, be diligent, but not too rugged, start him, but afright him not.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: Phew are you there?

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: We come to see you Nephew, be not angry;

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why doe you dogge me thus, with these strange people, why all the world shall never make me rich more, nor master of these troubles.

sp.speaker: Tennants.
sp.p: We beseech you for our poore childrens sake.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Who bid you get um: have you not thrashing worke enough, but children must be baugd out oth' sheafe too, other men with all their delicates, and healthfull diets, can get but winde egges: you with a clove of garlicke a peece of cheese would breake a saw, and sowre milke, and I must maintaine these tumblers.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: You ought to maintaine us, wee have maintained you, and when you slept provided for you; who bought the silke you weare, I thinke our labours; reckon, youle find it so: who found your horses perpetuall pots of ale, maintain'd your Tavernes, and who extold you in the halfe crowne boxes, where you might sit and mu •… er all the beauties, wee had no band in these, no we are puppies:
Your tennants base vexations.

sp.speaker: Ʋall.
sp.p: Very well sir.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Had you Land, and honest men to serve your purposes, honest, and faithfull, and will you run away from um, betray your selfe, and your poore tribe to misery; morgage all us, like old cloakes; where will you hunt next you had a thousand acres, faire and open: The Kings bench is enclosed, thers no good riding, the Cou • ter is full of thornes and brakes, take heed sir, and bogges, youle quickly finde what broth they're made of.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yare short and pithie.

sp.speaker: Lance
sp.p: They say yare a fine Gentleman, and excellent judgment, they report you have a wit; keepe your selfe out oth raine and take your Cloake with you, which by interpretation is your state sir or I shall thinke your fame belyed you, you have money and may have meanes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
I prethee leave prating, does my good lye within thy braine to further, or my undoing in thy pitty: goe, goe, get you home, there whistle to your horses, and let them edifie, away, sow hempe, and hang your selves withall, what
am I to you, or you to me; am I your Landlord puppies?

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: This is uncivill.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: More unmercifull you, to vex me with these bacon broth and puddings, they are the walking shapes of all my sorrowes:

sp.speaker: 3. Tennants.
sp.p: Your Fathers Worship, would have used us better.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: My Fathers worship, was a foole.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Hey, hey boyes, old Vallentine ifaith, the old boy still.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Fie Cosen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I meane besotted to his state, he had never left mee the misery of so much meanes else, which till I sold was a meere meagrome to me: If you will talke, turne out these tenements, they are as killing to my nature Vncle, as water to a feaver.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: We will goe, but it is like Rammes to come againe the stronger, and you shall keepe your state:

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Thou lyest, I will not.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Sweete sir, thou lyest, thou shalt, and so good morrow. Exeunt Tennants.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: This was my man, and of a noble breeding, now to your businesse Vncle.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: To your state then.

sp.speaker: Val,
sp.p: Tis gone, and I am glad on't, name it no more, tis that I pray against, and heaven has heard mee, I tell you sir, I am more fearefull of it, I meane of thinking of more lands, or livings, then sickely men are travelling a Sundaies, for being queld with Carryers out upont caveat emptor, let the foole out sweat it that thinkes he has got a catch out.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: This is madnesse to be a willfull begger.

sp.speaker: Ʋa.
sp.p: I am mad then and so I meane to be, will that content you, how bravely now I live, how jocund, how neare the first inheritance, without feares, how free from title troubles.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: And from meanes too.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p:
Meanes, why all good men's my meanes, my wits my plow, the Townes my stock, Tavernes my standing house, and all the world knowes theres no want, all Gentlemen that
love society, love me; all purses that wit and pleasure opens, are my Tennants; every mans clothes fit me, the next faire lodging, is but my next remoove, and when I please to remoove; and when I please to be more eminent, and take the aire, a peece, is levied, and a Coach prepared, and I goe I care not whether, what neede state here.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: But say these meanes were honest, will they last sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Far longer then your jerkin, and weare fairer, should I take ought of you, tis true, I begd now, or which is worse then that, I stole a kindnesse, and which is worst of all, I lost my way int, your mindes enclosed, nothing lies open nobly, your very thoughts are hid, that worke on nothing but daily sweate, and trouble: were my way so full of dirt as this, tis true I shifted; are my acquaintance Grasiers: but sir, know no man that I am allyed too, in my living, but makes it equal, whether his owne use, or my necessity pull first, nor is this forc'd, but the meere quallity and poysure of goodnesse, and doe you thinke I venter nothing equall.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: You pose me Cosen.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Whats my knowledge Vncle, ist not worth money, whats my understanding, my travell, reading, wit, all these digested, my daily making men, some to speake, that too much flegme had frozen up, some other that spoke too much to hold their peace, and put their tongues to pensions, some to weare their clothes, and some to keepe um, these are nothing Vncle; besides these wayes, to teach the way of nature, a manly love, community to all that are deservers, not examining how much, or whats done for them, tis wicked, and such a one like you, chewes his thoughts double, making um onely food for his repentance.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: This cloake and hat sir, and my Masters love.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Commend's to thy Master, and take that, and leave um at my lodging.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: I shall doe it sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I doe not thinke of these things:

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: Please you sir, I have gold here for you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Give it me, drinke that and commend me to thy Master;
looke you Vncle, doe I begge these:

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: No sure tis your worth sir.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Tis like enough, but pray satisfie mē, are not these wayes as honest as persecuting the starved inheritance, with musty Corne, the very rats were faine to run away from, or selling rotten wood by the pound, like spices, which Gentlemen doe after burne byth ounces, doe not I know your way of feeding beasts, with graines, and windy stuffe, to blow up butchers, your racking pastures, that have eaten up as many singing Shepherds, and their issues, as Andeluria breedes; these are authentique, I tell you sir, I would not change wayes with you, unlesse it were to sell your state, that houre, and if it were possible to spend it then too, for all your Beanes in Rumnillo, now you know me.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: I would you knew your selfe, but since you are growne such a strange enemy, to all that fits you, give mee leave to make your brothers fortune.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: From your morgage, which yet you may recover, Ile finde the meanes.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Pray save your labour sir, my brother and my selfe, will runne one fortune, and I thinke what I hold a meere vexation, cannot be safe from him, I love him better, he has wit at will, the world has meanes, hee shall live without this tricke of state, we are heires both, and all the world before us.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: My last offer, and then I am gone.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What ist, and then Ile answer.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: What thinke you of a Wife yet to restore you, and tell me seriously without these trifles.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: And you can finde one, that can please my fancy, you shall not finde me stubborne.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Speake your woman.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p:
One without eyes, that is selfe commendations, for when they finde they are hansome, they are unholsome, one without eares, not giving time to flatterers, for shee that heares her selfe commended, wavers, and points men out a way to make um wicked, one without substance of her selfe,
that woman without the pleasure of her life, thats wanton, though she be young, forgetting it, though faire, making her glasse the eyes of honest men, not her owne admiration, all her ends obedience all her houres new blessings, if there may be such a woman:

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Yes there may be.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And without state too.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: You are disposed to trifle, well, fare you well sir, when you want me next, youle seeke me out a better sence.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Farewell Vncle, and as you love your estate, let not me heare on't.

lg.l: It shall not trouble you, Ile watch him still,
And when his friends fall of, then bend his will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I know the cause of all this sadnesse now, your sister has ingrost all the brave lovers.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Shee has wherewithall, much good may doe her, prethee speake softly, we are open to mens eares:

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Feare not, we are safe, we may see all that passe, heare all, and make our selves merry with their language, and yet stand undiscovered, bee not melancholly, you are as faire as shee.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Who I, I thanke you, I am as haste ordain'd mee, a thing slubberd, my sister is a goodly portly Lady, a woman of a presence, she spreads satten, as the Kings ships doe canvas, every where she may spare me her misen, and her bonnets strike her maine petticoate, and yet outsaile me, I am a Carvell to her.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: But a tight one:

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: She is excellent, well built too.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: And yet shees old.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Shee never saw above one voyage Luce, and credit me after another, her hull will serve againe, and a right good Merchant, shee plaies and sings too, dances and discourses, comes very neere essaies a pretty poet, begins to piddle with Phylosophie, a subtill Chimicke wench, and can extract the spirit of mens estates, she has the light before her, and cannot misse her choice, for me tis reason, I waite my meane fortune.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: You are so bashfull.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: It is not at first word up and ride, thou art cosend, that would shew mad I faith, besides, wee lose the meane part of our polliticke government, if we become provokers, then wee are faire, and fit for mens imbraces, when like townes, they lie before us ages, yet not carried, hold out their strongest batteries, then compound too with the losse of honour, and march oft with our faire wedding: Colours flying, who are these?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I know not, nor I care not.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Prethee peace then, a well bult Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: But poorely thatcht.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Has he devoured you too?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Has gulped me downe Lance.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Left you no meanes to study.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Not a farthing: dispatcht my poore annuity I thanke him, heres all the hope I have left, one bare ten shillings.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: You are fit for great mens services.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I am fit, but who'le take me, thus mens miseries are now accounted staines in their natures, I have travelled, and I have studyed long, observed all kingdomes, know all the promises of Art and manners, yet that I am not bold, nor cannot flatter, I shall not thrive, all these are but vaine Studies, art thou so rich as to get me a lodging Lance.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Ile sell the titles of my house else, my Horse, my Hawke, nay 's death Ile pawne my wife: Oh Mr. Francis, that I should see your Fathers house fall thus.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: An honest fellow.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Your Fathers house, that fed me, that bred up all my name.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: A gratefull fellow.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: And fall by.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Peace, I know you are angry Lance, but I must not heare with whom, he is my brother, & though you hold him slight, my most deare brother: A gentleman excepting some few rubbes, he were too excellent to live here else, fraughted as deepe with noble and brave parts, issues of a noble and manly spirit as any he a live, I must not heare you, though I
am miserable, and he made me so, yet still he is my brother, still I love him, and to that tye of blood linke my affections.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: A noble nature, dost thou know him Luce?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: No Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Jsab.
sp.p: Thou shouldest ever know such good men, what a faire body and a mind, are married there together; did he not say he wanted.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Whats that to you?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Tis true, but tis great pitty.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: How she changes, ten thousand more than he, as handsome men too.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Tis like enough, but as I live, this Gentleman among ten thousand thousand, is there no knowing him; why should he want? fellowes of no merit, slight and puft soules, that walke like shadowes, by leaving no print of what they are, or poise, let them complaine.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Her colour changes strangely.

sp.speaker: Isah.
sp.p: This man was made, to mark his wants to waken us, alas poore Gentleman, but will that fledge him, keepe him from cold, beleeve me he is well bred, and cannot be but of a noble linnage, mark him, and marke him well.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: 'Is a hansome man.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: The sweetnesse of his suffrance sets him off, O Luce, but whether goe I.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: You cannot hide it.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I would he had what I can spare.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Tis charitable.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Come sir, Ile see you lodged, you have tied my tongue fast, Ile steale before you want, tis but a hanging.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Thats a good fellow too, an honest fellow, why, this would move a stone, I must needes know; but that some other time. Exit Lance. and Fran.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Is the winde there? that makes for me.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Come, I forgot a businesse.

div.head: Scaena 1.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: MY sister, and a woman of so base a pitty, what was the fellow?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Why an ordinary man Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Poore?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Poore enough, and no man knowes from whence neither.

sp.speaker: Wed.
sp.p: What could she see?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Onely his misery, for else she might behold a hundred handsumer.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Did she change much.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Extreamely, when he spoke, and then her pitty like an Orator, I feare her love framed such a commendation, and followed it so farre, as made me wonder.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Is she so hot, or such a want of lovers, that shee must doate upon afflictions: why do's shee not goe romage all the Prisons, and there bestow her youth, bewray her wantonnesse, and flie her honour, common both to beggery; did she speake to him?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: No, hee saw us not, but ever since, she hath beene mainely troubled.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Was he young?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Yes young enough.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And looked he like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Like such a Gentleman, would pawne ten oathes for twelve pence.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: My sister, and sinke basely; this must not be, do's she use meanes to know him?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Yes Madam, and has employed a Squire called Shorthose.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
O thats a precious Knave, keepe all this private, but still be neere her lodging; Luce what you can gather by any meanes, let me understand, Ile stoppe her heate, and turne her charitie another way, to blesse her selfe first, be still close to
her Councells, a begger and a stranger, theres a blessednesse, Ile none of that, I have a toy yet sister, shall tell you this is foule, and make you find it, and for your paines take you the last gowne I wore, this makes me mad, but I shall force a remedy.

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.p: Sirra, we have so lookt thee, and long'd for thee, this Widdow is the strangest thing, the stateliest, and stands so much upon her excellencies.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: She has put us off this moneth now, for an answer.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: No man must visit her, nor looke upon her, not say good morrow nor good even, till thats past.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: She has found what dough you are made of, and so kneads you, are you good at nothing, but these aftergames, I have told you often enough what things they are, what precious things, these widdowes.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: If we had um.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why the devill has not craft enough to woe um, there be three kindes of fooles, marke this note gentlemen, marke it, and understand it.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.p: Well, goe forward.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: An Innocent, a Knave foole, a foole politicke: the last of which are lovers, widdow lovers.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Will you allow no Fortune?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No such blind one.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.p: We gave you reasons, why twas needfull for us.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: As you are those fooles, I did allow those reasons, but as my Schollers and companions damn'd um, doe you know what it is to wooe a widdow, answer me coolely now, and understandingly.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Why to lie with her, and to enjoy her wealth.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Why there you are fooles still, craftie to catch your selves, pure polliticke fooles, I lookt for such an answer, once more heare me, it is to wed a widdow, to be doubted mainely, whether the state you have be yours or no, are those old bootes you ride in, marke me, widdowes are long extents in Law upon newes, livings upon their bodies winding-sheetes, they that enjoy um, lie but with dead mens monuments, and beget onely their owne ill Epitaphs, Is not this
plaine now?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Plaine spoken.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And plaine truth, but if you'le needes doe things of danger, doe but loose your selves, not any part concernes your understandings, for then you are Meacockes, fooles, and miserable, march of a maine, within an inch of a Fircug, turne me oth' toe like a Weathercocke, kill every day a Sergeant for a twelve moneth, robbe the Exchequor, and burne all the roules, and these will make a shew.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: And these are trifles.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Considered to a Widdow, ēmptie nothing, for here you venture but your persons, there the varnish of your persons, your discretions, why tis a monstrous thing to marry at all, especially as now tis made, me thinkes a man, an understanding man, is more wise to me, and of a nobler tie, than all these trinkets, what doe we get by women, but our senses, which is the rankest part about us satisfied, and when thats done what are we? Crest falne cowards, what benefite can children be, but charges and disobedience, whats the love they render at one and twentie yeares; I pray die father; when they are young, they are like bells rung backwards, nothing but noise, and giddinesse, and come to yeares once, there droppes a sonne, byth' sword in's Mistresses quarrell, a great joy to his parents: a daughter ripe too, growes high and lustie in her blood, must have a heating, runnes away with a supple hand Servingman, his twentie nobles spent, takes to a trade, and learnes to spinne mens haire off; theres another, and most are of this nature, will you marry?

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.p: For my partyes, for any doubt I feele yet.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And this same Widdow?

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.p: If I may, and me thinkes, how ever you are pleased to dispute these dangers, such a warme match, and for you sir, were not hurtfull.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Not halfe so killing as for you, for mee shee cannot with all the Art shee has, make mee more miserable, or much more fortunate, I have no state left, a benefit that none of you can bragge of, and theres the Antidote against a Widdow, nothing to lose, but that my soule
inherits, which shee can neither law nor claw away to that, but little flesh, it were too much else; and that unholsome too, it were too rich else; and to all this contempt of what shee do's J can laugh at her teares, neglect her angers, heare her without a faith, so pitty her as if shee were a traytor, moane her person, but deadly hate her pride; if you could doe these, and had but this discretion and like fortune, it were but an equall venture.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.p: This is mallice.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: When shee lies with your land, and not with you, growes great with joyntures, and is brought to bed with all the state you have, you'le finde this certaine; but is it come to passe you must marry, is there no buffe will hold you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Grant it be so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Then chuse the tamer evill, take a maide, a maide not worth a penny; make her yours, knead her, and mould her yours, a maide worth nothing, theres a vertuous spell, in that word nothing; a maide makes conscience of halfe a crowne a weeke for pinnes and puppits, a maide content with one Coach and two horses, not falling out because they are not matches; with one man satisfied, with one raine guided, with one faith, one content, one bed, aged shee makes the wife, preserves the fame and issue; a Widdow is a Christmas box that sweepes all.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.p: Yet all this cannot sinke us.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are my friends, and a I my loving friends, I spend your money, yet I deserve it too, you are my friendes still, I ride your horses, when I want I sell um; I eate your meate, helpe to weare her linnen, sometimes I make you drunke, and then you seale, for which Ile doe you this commoditie, be ruled, and let me try her, I will discover her, the truth is, I will never leave to trouble her, till I see through her, then if I finde her worthy.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: This was our meaning Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Tis done then, I must want nothing.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Nothing but the woman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
No jealousie, for when I marry, the devill must be wiser than I take him; and the flesh foolisher, comes lets to
dinner, and when I am well whetted with wine, have at her.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: But art thou sure.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: No suerer then I heard.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: That it was that flouting fellowes brother.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Yes, Shorthose told me so.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: He did search out the truth.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: It seemes he did.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Pre thee Luce, call him hether, if he be no worse, I never repent my pitty, now sirra, what was he wee sent you after, the Gentleman ith blacke.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Ith torne blacke.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Yes, the same sir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: What would your Worship with him.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Why my worship would know his name, and what he is.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: 'Is nothing, he is a man, and yet he is no man.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You must needes play the foole;

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Tis my profession.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: How is he a man, and no man.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Hees a begger, onely the signe of a man, the bush puld downe, which showes the house stands emptie.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Whats his calling?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: They call him begger:

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Whats his kindred:

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Beggers.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: His worth.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: A learned begger, a poore Scholler:

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: How does he live.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Like wormes, he eares old Bookes.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Is Ʋallentine his brother.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: His begging brother.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: What may his name be?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Leave your fooling.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: You had as good say, leave your living.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Once more tell me his name directly:

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Ile be hangd first, unlesse I heard him Christned, but I can tell what foolish people call him.

sp.speaker: Jsa.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Where lies this learning sir?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: In Paules Church yard forsooth.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I meane that Gentleman, foole.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: O that foole, hee lies in loose sheetes every where, thats no where.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: You have gleand since you came to London, in the Countrey Shorthose, you were an arrant foole, a dull cold coxcombe, here every Taverne teaches you, the pint pot has so belaboured you, with wit, your brave acquaintance that gives you ale, so fortified your mazard, that now theres no talking to you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Is much improved, a fellow, a fine discourser.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I hope so, I have not waited at the taile of wit, so long to be an asse.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: But say now Shorthose, my Lady should remoove into the Countrie.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I had as leeve she should remoove to heaven, and as soone I would undertake to follow her.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Where no old Charnico is, nor no Anchoves, nor Master such a one, to meete at the Rose, and bring my Lady such a ones chiefe Chambermaide.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: No bouncing healths to this brave Lad, deare Shorthose, nor downe oth knees to that illustrious Lady.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: No fidles, nor no lusty noyse of drawer, carry this pottle to my father, Shorthose.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: No playes, nor gally foistes, no strange Embassadors to runne and wonder at, till thou beest oyle, and then come home againe, and lye bith Legend.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Say she should goe.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: If I say so, Ile bee hangd first, or if I thought shee would goe:

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I would goe with her.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: But Shorthose, where thy heart is:

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Doe not fright him.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: By this hand Mistris tis a noyse, a loud one too, and from her owne mouth, presently to be gone too, but why, or to what end?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: May not a man dye first, sheele give him so much time.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Gone oth' sudden; thou dost but jest, shee must not mocke the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: She has put them off a moneth, they dare not see her, beleeve me Mistris, what I heare I tell you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Is this true wench, gone on so short a warning, what tricke is this, she never told me of it, it must not be: sirra, attend me presently, you know I have beene a carefull friend unto you, attend me in the hall, and next be faithfull, cry not, we shall not goe.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Her Coach may cracke. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ʋall.
sp.p: Which way to live, how darest thou come to towne, to aske such an idle question.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Me thinkes tis necessary, unlesse you could restore that annuity you have tippled up in Tavernes:

sp.speaker: Val,
sp.p: Where hast thou beene, and how brought up Franscisco, that thou talkest thus out of France, thou wert a pretty fellow, and of a hansome knowledge; who has spoyld thee:

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: He that has spoyld himselfe, to make himselfe sport, and by his Coppie, will spoile all comes neere him, buy but a glasse, if you be yet so wealthy, and looke there who?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Well said old Coppihold.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: My hearts good freehold sir, and so youle finde it, this Gentleman your brother, your hopefull brother, for there is no hope of you, use him thereafter:

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Ene aswell as I use my selfe, what wouldst thou have Francke.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Can you procure me a hundred pound:

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Harke what he saies to you, O try your wits, they say you are excellent at it, for your land has laine long bed rid, and unsensible.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And Ile forget all wrongs, you see my state, and to what wretchednesse, your will has brought me; but what it may be, by this benefit, if timely done, and like a noble brother, both you and I may feele, and to our comforts:

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: (A hundred pound) dost thou know what thou hast said boy:

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I said a hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Thou hast said more, then any man can justifie beleeve it, procure a hundred pounds, I say to thee, theres no such summe in nature, fortie shillings there may be now ith Mint, and thats a treasure, I have seene five pound, but let me tell it, and tis as wonderfull, as Calves with five legges, heeres five shillings Francke, the harvest of five weekes, and a good crop too, take it, and pay thy first fruites, Ile come downe and eate it out.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Tis patience must meete with you sir, not love.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Deale roundly, and leave these fiddle faddles:

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Leave thy prating, thou thinkest thou art a notable wise fellow, thou and thy rotten Sparrow hawke; two of the reverent.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I thinke you are mad, or if you be not will be, with the next moone, what would you have him doe.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: To get money first, thats to live, you have shewed him how to want.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Slife, how doe I live, why, what dull foole would aske that question, three hundred three pilds more, I and live bravely, the better halfe oth towne, and live most gloriously, aske them what states they have, or what annuities, or when they pray for seasonable harvests, thou hast a hansome wit, stirre into the world, Francke, stirre, for shame, thou art a pretty Scholler, aske how to live, write, write, write any thing, the worlds a fine beleeving world, write newes.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Dragons in Sussex sir, or fierie battles seene in the aire at Aspurge.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Theres the way Francke, and in the taile of these, fright me the Kingdome with a sharpe Prognostication, that shal scowre them, dearth upon dearth, like leven taffaties, predictions
of Sea breaches, warres, and want of herrings on our coast, with bloody noses.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Whirle windes, that shall take of the toppe of Grantam steeple, and clap it on Poules, and after these, a I envoy to the Citty for their sinnes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Probatum est, thou canst not want a pension, go switch me up a Covey of young Schollers, theres twenty nobles, and two loades of coales, are not these ready wayes. Cosmography thou art deepely read in, draw me a mappe from the Mermaide, I meane a midnighe mappe to scape the watches, and such long sencelesse examinations, and Gentlemen shall feede thee, right good Gentlemen, I cannot stay long.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: You have read learnedly, and would you have him follow these megeras, did you beginne with ballads.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Well, J will leave you, J see my wants are growne ridiculous, yours may be so, I will not curse you neither; you may thinke, when these wanton fits are over, who bred me, and who ruined me, looke to your selfe sir, a providence J waite on.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Thou art passionate, hast thou beene brought up with girles.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Rest you merry Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not so merry as you suppose sir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Pray stay a while, and let mee take a view of you, I may put my spoone into the wrong pottage pot else.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why wilt thou muster us.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: No you are not he, you are a thought too hansome.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Who wouldst thou speake withall, why doest thou peepe so?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I am looking birds nests, I can finde none in your bush beard, J would speake with you blacke Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: With me my friend.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Yes sure, and the best friend sir, it seemes you spake withall this twelve moneths Gentleman, theres money for you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p:
Theres none for you sir, be not so briefe, not a penny,
law how he itches at it, stand of, you stirre my colour.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Take it, tis money.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: You are too quicke too, first be sure you have it, you seeme to be a Faulckoner, but a foolish one.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Take it, and say nothing:

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: You are cosend too, tis take it, and spent it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: From whom came it sir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Such another word, and you shall have none out.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: J thanke you sir, I doubly thanke you.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Well sir, then buy you better clothes, and get your hat drest, and your Laundresse to wash your bootes white.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pray stay sir, may you not be mistaken.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I thinke I am, give me the money again, come quick, quicke, quicke.

sp.speaker: Fran
sp.p: I would be loath to render, till I am sure it bē so.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Harke in your eare, is not your name Franscisco.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Be quiet then, it may thunder a hundred times, before such stones fall; doe not you neede it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: And tis thought you have it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I thinke I have.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Then hold it fast, tis not flyblowne, you may pay for the poundage, you forget your selfe, I have not seene a Gentleman so backward, a wanting Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Your mercy sir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Freind you have mercy, a whole bagge full of mercy, be merry with it, and be wise.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I would faine, if it please you, but know.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: It does not please me, tell over your money and be not mad boy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You have no more such bagges:

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: More such there are sir, but few I feare for you, I have cast your water, you have wit, you need no money. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Be not amazed sir tis good gold, good old gold, this is restorative, and in good time, it comes to doe you good, keepe it and use it, let honest fingers feele it, yours be too quicke sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He named me, and he gave it me, but from whom.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Let um send more, and then examine it, this can be but a preface.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Being a stranger, of whom can I deserve this.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Sir, of any man that has but eyes, and manly understanding to finde mens wants, good men are bound to doe so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Now you see Francke, there are more waies then certainties, now you beleeve: What plow brought you this harvest, what sale of timber, coales, or what annuities, these feede no hindes, nor waite the expectation of quarter dayes, you see it showers into you, you are an asse, lie plodding, and lie fooleing, about this blazing starre, and that bo peepe, whyneing, and fasting, to finde the naturall reason why a dogge turnes twice about before he lie downe, what use of these, or what joy in annuities, where every mans thy studdy, and thy tennant, I am ashamed on thee:

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Yes I have seene this fellow, theres a wealthy Widdow hard by.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes marry is there.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I thinke hees her servant, J am cosend if after her, I am sure ont.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I am glad ont.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Shees a good woman.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I am gladder:

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: And young enough beleeve.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I am gladder of all sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Franck, you shall lye with me soone.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I thanke my money:

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: His money shall lie with mee, three in a bed sir will be too much this weather.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Meete me at the Mermaide, and thou shalt see what things —

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Trust to your selfe sir. Exeunt Fran, and Vall.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.p: O Vallentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How now, why doe you looke so.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: The Widdowes going man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why let her goe man.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Shees going out oth Towne.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The Townes the happier, I would they were all gone

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.p: We cannot come to speake with her.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Not to speake to her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: She will be gone within this houre, either now Valle.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.p: Hare. Now, now, now, good Vall.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I had rather march ith mouth oth Cannon, but adiew, if she be above ground, goe, away to your praiers, away I say, away, she shall be spoken withall. Exeunt

div.stage: Enter Shorthose with one boote on, Roger & Humphrey.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: She will goe Shorthose.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Who can helpe it Roger?

sp.speaker: Within Raphe.
sp.p: Roger helpe downe with the hangings.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: By and by Raph, I am making up oth trunckes here.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: Who lookes to my Ladies Wardrobe? Humphrey.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Heere.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: Downe with the boxes in the gallery, and bring away the Coach Cushions.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Will it not raine, no conjuring abroad, nor no devises to stop this journey.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Why goe now, why now, why oth sudden, now what preparation, what horses have we ready, what provision laid in ith Country.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Not an egge I hope.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: No nor one drop of good drink boyes, ther's the devil.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I heartily pray the malt be musty, and then we must come up againe.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: What saies the Steward?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Hees at's wits end, for some foure houres since, out of his haste and providence, he mistooke the Millers maunjey mare, for his owne nagge.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: And she may breake his necke, and save the journey, oh London how I love thee.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: I have no bootes, nor none Ile buy (or if I had) refuse me if I would venture my abillity, before a cloake bagge, men are men.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p:
For my part, if I be brought, as I know it will be aimed at, to carry any durty dairy creame pot, or any gentle Lady of the Laundry, chambring, or wantonnesse behinde my gelding, with all her streamers, knapsackes, glasses, gugawes,
as if I were a running slippery, Ile give um leave to cut my girts, and flay me. Ile not be troubled with their distibations, at every halfe miles end, I understand my selfe, and am resolved.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: To morrow night at Olivers, who shalbe there boyes, who shall meete the wenches.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: The well brued stand of Ale, we should have met at.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: These griefes like to another tale of Troy, would mollifie the hearts of barbarous people, and Tom Butcher weepe Eneas enters, and now the townes lost.

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.p: Why whether run you, my Lady is mad.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I would she were in Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.p: The carts are come, no hands to helpe to load um, the stuffe lies in the hall, the plate:

sp.speaker: Within Widdow.
sp.p: Why knaves there, where be these idle fellowes

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Shall I ride with one boote.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why where I say:

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.p: Away, away, it must be so.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: O for a tickling storme, to last but ten dayes. Exeunt

div.head: Scaen, 1.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: BY my troth Mistris I did it for the best:

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: It may be so, but Luce, you have a tongue: a dish of meate in your mouth, which if it were minced Luce, would doe a great deale better.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I protest Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: It will be your owne one time or others: Walter.

sp.speaker: Walter within:
sp.p: Anon forsooth.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Lay my hat ready, my fanne and cloake, you are so full of providence; and Walter, tucke up my little box behinde the Coach, and bid my maide make ready, my sweete service to your good Lady Mistresse; and my dog, good let the Coachman carry him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But heare me.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
I am in love sweete Luce, and you are so skillfull, that I
must needes undoe my selfe; and heare me, let Oliver packe up my glasse discreetly, and see my Curles well carried, O sweete Luce, you have a tongue, and open tongues have open you know what Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Pray you be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Yes and contented too, before I leave you: theres a Roger, which some call a Butcher, I speake of certainties, I doe not fish Luce, nay doe not stare, I have a tongue can talke too: and a greene Chamber Luce, a backe doore opens to a long gallery; there was a night Luce, doe you perceive, doe you perceive me yet: O doe you blush Luce: a Friday night I saw your Saint Luce; for tother box of Marmaladde, alls thine sweete Roger, this I heard and kept too.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Ene as you are a woman Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: This I allow as good and physicall sometimes these meetings, and for the cheering of the heart; but Luce, to have your owne turne served, and to your friend to be a dogbolt.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I confesse it Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: As you have made my sister Iealous of me, and foolishly, and childishly pursued it, I have found out your haunt, and traced your purposes, for which mine honour suffers, your best wayes must be applied to bring her backe againe, and seriously and suddenly, that so I may have a meanes to cleare my selfe, and she a faire opinion of me, else you peevish —

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: My power and prayers Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Whats the matter.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I have beene with the Gentleman, he has it, much good may doe him with it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Come are you ready, you love so to delay time, the day growes on.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I have sent for a few triffles, when those are come; And now I know your reason.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Know your owne honour then, about your businesse, see the Coach ready presently, Ile tell you more then;

And understand it well, you must not thinke my sister, so
tender eyed as not to see your follies, alas I know your heart, and must imagine, and truely too; tis not your charitie can coyne such sums to give a way as you have done, in that you have no wisedome Isabel, no nor modestie where nobler uses are at home; I tell you, I am ashamed to finde this in your yeares, farre more in your discretion, none to chuse but things for pittie, none to seale your thoughts on, but one of no abiding, of no name; nothing to bring you but this, cold and hunger: A jolly Ioynture sister, you are happy, no mony, no not tenne shillings.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You search nearely.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I know it as I know your folly, one that know not where he shall eate his next meale, take his rest, unlesse it be in th • stockes; what kindred has he, but a more wanting brother, or what vertues.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You have had rare intelligence, I see sister.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Or say the man had vertue, is vertue in this age a full inheritance: what Ioynture can he make you, Plutarchs Moralls, or so much peenny rent in the small pots, this is not well, tis weake, and I grive to know it.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: And this you quit the towne for.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Its not time.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You are better read in my affaires than I am, thats all I have to answer, Ile goe with you, and willingly, and what you thinke most dangerous, Ile sit and laugh at.
For sister tis not folly but good discretion governes our maine fortunes.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I am glad to heare you say so.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I am for you.

div.stage: Enter Shorthose and Humphrey with riding rods.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: The devill cannot stay her, she'le ont, eate an egge now, and then we must away.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p:
I am gaulled already, yet I will pray may London wayes from henceforth be full of holes, and Coaches cracke their wheeles, may zealous Smithes so housell all our Hackneyes, that they may feele compunction in their feete, and tire at Highgate, may it raine above all Almanackes till carriers saile, and the Kings Fishmonger ride like Bike Arion upon
a Trout to London.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: At S. Albones, let all the Innes be drunke, not an Host sober to bid her worship welcome.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Not a Fiddle, but all preacht downe with Puritans; no meate but legges of beefe.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: No beds but Woollpackes.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: And those so crammed with warrens of sterved Fleas that bite like bandogges: let Mims be angry at their S. Bellswagger, and we passe in the heate ont and be beaten, beaten abominably, beaten horse and man, and all my Ladies linnen sprinkled with suddes and dish water.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Not a wheele but out of joynt.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Why dost thou laugh.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Theres a Gentleman, and the rarest Gentleman, and makes the rarest sport.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Where, where?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Within here, has made the gayest sport with Tom the Coachman, so tewed him up with sacke that hee lies lashing a butt of Malmsie for his Mares.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Tis very good.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: And talkes and laughes, and singes the rarest songs, and Shorthose, he has so mauld the red Deere pies, made such an almes ith butterie.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Better still. Enter Ʋall. Widdow.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: My Lady in a rage with the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: May he anger her into a feather. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I pray tell me, who sent you hether? for I imagine it is not your condition you looke so temperately, and like a Gentleman, to aske me these milde questions.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Doe you thinke I use to walke of errands gentle Lady, or deale with women out of dreames from others.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You have not knowne me sure?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not much.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What reason have you then to be so tender of my credit, you are no kinsman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: If you take it so, the honest office that I came to doe you, is not so heavy but I can returne it: now I perceive you are too proud, not worth my visit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray stay, a little proud.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Monstrous proud, I grieve to heare a woman of your value, and your abundant parts stung by the people, but now J see tis true, you looke upon mee as if I were a rude and sawcie fellow that borrowed all my breeding from a dunghill, or such a one, as should now fall and worship you in hope of pardon: you are cosen'd Lady, I came to prove opinion a loud lier, to see a woman onely great in goodnesse, and Mistresse of a greater fame than fortune, but—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are a strange Gentleman, if I were proud now, I should be monstrous angry, which J am not, and shew the effects of pride; I should dispise you but you are welcome sir: To thinke well of our selves, if we deserve it, is a luster in us, and every good we have, strives to show gracious, what use is it else, old age like Seer trees, is seldome seene affected, stirs sometimes at rehearsall of such acts his daring youth endeavour'd.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: This is well, and now you speake to the purpose, you please me, but to be place proud:

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: If it be our owne, why are we set here with distinction else, degrees, and orders given us, in you men, tis held a coolenesse if you lose your right afronts, and losse of honour: streetes, and walls, and upper ends of tables, had they tongues could tell what blood has followed, and what fude about your rankes; are we so much below you, that till you have us, are the toppes of nature, to be accounted drones, without a difference, you will make us beasts indeed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay worse then this too proud of your cloathes, they sweare a Mercers Lucifer, a tumer tackt together by a Taylor, nay yet worse proud of red and white, a varnish that buttermilke can better.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Lord how little will vex these poore blinde people, if my cloathes be sometimes gay and glorious, does it follow my minde must be my Mercers too, or say my beauty please some weake eyes, must it please them to thinke that blowes mee up, that every houre blowes of: this is an Infants anger.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Thus they say too, what though you have a Coach
lined through with velvet and foure faire Flaunders Mares, why should the streets be troubled continually with you, till Carmen curse you, can there be ought in this but pride of shew Lady, and pride of bum-beating, till the learned lawyers with their fat bagges, are thrust against the bulkes, till all their Cases cracke; why should this Lady, and tother Lady, and the third sweete Ladie, and Madam at mile end, be dailie visited, and your poorer neighbours, with course napses neglected, fashions conferd about, pouncings, and paintings, and young mens bodies read on like Anotamies.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are very credulous, and somewhat desperate to deliver this sir, to her you know not, but you shall confesse me, and finde I will not start; in us all meetings lie open to these leud reports, and our thoughts at Church, our very meditations some will sweare, which all should feare to judge, at least uncharitably, are mingled with your memories, cannot sleepe, but this sweet Gentleman swimmes in our fancies, that scarlet man of warre, and that smooth Senior; not dresse our heads without new ambushes how to surprise that greatnesse or that glory; our very smiles are subject to constructions; nay sir, its come to this, we cannot pish, but tis a favour for some foole or other: should we examine you thus, wert not possible to take you without Prospectives.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It may be, but these excuse not.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nor yours force no truth sir. what deadly tongues you have, and to those tongues what hearts, and what inventions; ah my conscience, and 'twere not for sharpe justice, you would venture to aime at your owne mothers, and account it glory to say you had done so; all you thinke are Counsells and cannot erre, tis we still that shew double, giddie, or gorg'd with passion; we that build Babells for mens confusions, we that scatter as day do's his warme light; our killing curses over Gods creatures next to the devills mallice: lets intreate your good words.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Well, this woman has a brave soule.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Are not we gaily blest then, and much beholding to you for your substance; you may doe what you list, we what beseemes us, and narrowly doe that too, and precisely, our
names are served in else at Ordinaries, and belcht a broad in Tavernes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O most brave Wench, and able to redeeme an age of women.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are no Whoremasters, alas no Gentlemen, it were an impudencie to thinke you vicious; you are so holy, handsome Ladies fright you, you are the coole things of the time, the temperance, meere emblems of the Law, and vales of Vertue, you are not daily mending like Dutch Watches, & plastering like old walls; they are not Gentlemen, that with their secret sinnes encrease our Surgeons, and lie in forraine Countries, for new sores; women are all these vices; you are not envious, false, covetous, vaineglorious, irreligious, drunken, revengefull, giddie-eyed, like Parrats, eaters of others honours.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are angry.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No by my troth, and yet I could say more too, for when men make me angry, I am miserable.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sure tis a man she could not beare it thus bravely else, it may be I am tedious.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Not at all sir, I am content at this time you should trouble me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are distrustfull.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Where I finde no truth sir.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Come, come you are full of passion.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Some I have, I were too neere the nature a god else.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are monstrous peevish.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Because they are monstrous foolish, and know not how to use that should trie me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I was never answered thus, was you never drunke Lady?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No sure, not drunke sir? yet I love good wine as I love health and joy of heart, but temperately, why doe you aske that question?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: For that sinne that they most charge you with, is this sinnes servant, they say you are mostrous.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What sir, what?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Most strangely.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It has a name sure.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Infinitly lustfull, without all bounds, they sweare you kild your husband.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Lets have it all for heavens sake, tis good mirth sir.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: They say you will have foure now, and those foure stucke in foure quarters like foure windes to coole you; will she not cry nor curse?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: On with your Story,

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: And that you are forcing out of dispensations with summes of money to that purpose.

sp.speaker: Wid,
sp.p: Foure husbands, should not I be blest sir; for example, Lord what should I doe with them, turne a Malt mill, or tyth them out like towne Bulls to my tennants, you come to make me angry, but you cannot.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Ile make you merry then, you are a brave woman, and in dispite of envie a right one, goe thy wayes, truth thou art as good a woman, as any Lord of them all can lay his legge over, I doe not often commend your sexe.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It seemes so, your commendations are so studied for.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I came to see you, and sift you into flower, to know your purenesse, and I have found you excellent I thanke you; continue so, and shew men how to tread, and women how to follow: get an husband, an honest man, you are a good woman, and live hedg'd in from scandall, let him be too an understanding man, and to that steedfast; tis pittie your faire Figure should miscarrie, and then you are fixt, farewell.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray stay a little, I love your company now you are so pleasant, and to my disposition set so even.

sp.speaker: Ʋa.
sp.p: I can no longer. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: As I live a fine fellow, this manly handsome bluntnesse, shewes him honest; what is he, or from whence? blesse me, foure husbands, how prettily he fooled me into vices, to stirre my jealousie and finde my nature, a proper Gentleman, I am not well oth' sudden, such a companion I could live and die with, his angers are meere mirth. Enter Isabella.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Come, come, I am ready.

sp.speaker: Wit
sp.p: Are you so?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
What ailes she, the Coach staies, and the people, the
day goes on, I am as ready now as you desire sister: sie, who stayes now, why doe you sit and poute thus.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Prethee be quiet, I am not well.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: For heavens sake lets not ride staggering in the night, come, pray you take some sweete meates in your pocket, if your stomacke—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I have a little businesse.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: To abuse me, you shall not finde new dreames, and new suspitions, to horse withall.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Lord who made you a Commander: hay ho, my heart.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Is the winde come thether, and coward like doe you lose your colours to um, are you sicke • th Velentine; sweete sister, come lets away, the countrey will so quicken you, and we shall live so sweetely: Luce, my Ladies cloake; nay, you have put me into such a gogge of going I would not stay for all the world; if I live here, you have so knocked this love into my head, that I shall love any body, and I finde my body, I know not how, so apt; pray lets be gone sister, I stand on thornes.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I prethee Isabella, I faith I have some businesse that concernes me, I will suspect no more, here, weare that for me, and Ile pay the hundred pound you owe your tayler.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I had rather goe, but—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Come walke within me, weele goe to Cardes, unsadle the horses.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: A Iubile, a Iubile, we stay boyes. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Vncle, Lance, Fountaine, Bellamore, Harebraine following.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Are they behinde us.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Close, close, speake aloud sir.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: I am glad my nephew has so much discretion at length to finde his wants: did she entertaine him.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Most bravely, nobly, and gave him such a welcome.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: For his owne sake doe you thinke.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Most certaine sir, and in his owne cause bestir'd himselfe too, and wan such liking from her, she dotes on him, has the command of all the house already.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: He deales not well with his friends.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Let him deale on, and be his owne friend, hee has most neede of her.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: I wonder they would put him.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: You are in the right out, a man that must raise himselfe, I knew he would cosen um, and glad I am he has, he watched occasion. and found it ith' nicke.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: He has deceived me.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: I told you howsoever he weel'd about, hee would charge whom at length, how I could laugh now, to thinke of these tame fooles.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Twas not well done, because they trusted him, yet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Harke you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: We are upon a businesse, pray excuse us, they have it home.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.p: Come let it worke good on Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.p: Tis true, he is a knave, I ever thought it.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: And we are fooles, tame fooles.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Come lets goe seeke him, he shall be hang'd before he colt us basely. Exit. Enter Isabella, Luce.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Art sure she loves him.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Am I sure I live? And I have clap on such a commendation on your revenge.

sp.speaker: Jsa.
sp.p: Faith, he is a pretty Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Handsome enough, and that her eye has found out.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: He talkes the best they say, and yet the maddest.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Has the right way.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: How is she?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Beares it well, as if she cared not, but a man may see with halfe an eye through all her forced behaviours, and finde who is her Vallantine.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Come lets goe see her, I long to prosecute.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: By no meanes Mistresse, let her take better hold first,

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I could burst now. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
Vpbraide me with your benefits, you Pilchers, you shotten, sold, slight fellowes, wast not I that undertooke you first from emptie barrells, and brought those barking mouthes that gaped like bung-holes to utter sence: where got you understanding? who taught you manners and apt
carriage to ranke your selves? who filed you in fit Tavernes, were those borne with your worships when you came hether? what brought you from the Vniversities of moment matter to allow you, besides your small bare sentences?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Tis well sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Long cloakes with two hand-rapiers, boot-hoses with penny-poses, and twentie fooles opinions, who looked on you but piping rites that knew you would be prising, and Prentises in Paules Church-yard, that sented your want of Brittanes Bookes. Enter Widdow, Luce, Harebraine.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.p: This cannot save you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Taunt my integretie you whelpes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You may talke the stocke wee gave you out, but see no further.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: You tempt our patience, we have found you out, and what your trust comes to, yeare well feathered, thanke us, and thinke now of an honest course, tis time; men now begin to looke, and narrowly into your tumbling trickes, they are stale.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Is not that he?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Tis he.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Be still and marke him.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: How miserable will these poore wretches be when I forsake um, but things have their neeessities, I am sorry, to what a vomit must they turne againe now to their owne deare dunghill breeding; never hope after I cast you off, you men of Motley, you most undone things below pittie, any that has a soule and sixe pence dares releeve you, my name shall barre that blessing; theres your cloake sir, keepe it close to you, it may yet preserve you a fortnight longer from the foole; your hat, pray be covered, and theres the sattin that your worships sent me, will serve you at a sizer yet.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.p: Nay faith sir, you may euē rubbe these out now.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No such relicke, nor the least ragge of such a sorded weakenesse shall keepe me warme, these breeches are mine owne, purchased, and paid for, without your compassion, and Christian bleeches founded in Blacke Friers, and so Ile maintaine um.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: So they seeme sir.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p:
Onely the thirteene shillings in these breeches, and the odde groat, I take it, shall be yours sir, a marke to know a knave by, pray preserve it, doe not displease me more, but
take it presently, now helpe me off with my bootes.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: We are no groomes sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: For once you shall be, doe it willingly, or by this hand Ile make you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: To our owne sir, we may apply our hands.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Theres your hangers, you may deserve a strong paire, and a girdle will hold you without buckles; now I am perfect, and now the proudest of your worships tell me I am beholding to you.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.p: No such matter.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: And take heede how you pitty me, tis dangerous, exceeding dangerous, to prate of pittie which are the poorer; you are now puppies; I without you, or you without my knowledge be rogues, and so be gone, be rogues and reply not, for if you doe —

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Onely thus much, and then wee'le leave you, the ayre is farre sharper than our anger sir, and these you may reserve to raile in warmer.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Pray have a care sir of your health. Exit Lovers.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Yes hoghounds, more than you can have of your wits; tis cold, and I am very sensible, extreamely cold too, yet I will not off, till I have shamed these rascalls; I have endured as ill heates as another, and every way if one could perish my body, you'le beare the blame ont; I am colder here, not a poore penny left. Vncle with a bagge.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Tas taken rarely, and now hees flead he will be ruled.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Too him, tew him, abuse him, and nip him close.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Why how now cosen, sunning your selfe this weather?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: As you see sir, in a hot fit, I thanke my friends.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: But cosen, where are your cloathes man, those are no inheritance, your scruple may compound with those I take it, this is no fashion cosen.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Not much followed, I must confesse; yet Vncle I determine to trie what may be done next Tearme.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: How came you thus sir, for you are strangely moved.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Ragges, toyes and triflles, fit onely for those fooles that first possessed um, and to those Knaves, they are rendred freemen Vncle, ought to appeare like innocents, old Adam, a faire Figge-leafe sufficient.

sp.speaker: Vncle.
sp.p:
Take me with you, were these your friends, that
clear'd you thus.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Hang friends, and even recknings that make friends.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: I thought till now, there had beene no such living, no such purchase, for all the rest is labour, as a list of honourable friends, doe not such men as you sir in liew of all your understandings, travells, and those great gifts of nature; aime at no more than casting off your coates, I am strangely cosend.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Should not the towne shake at the cold you feele now, and all the Gentry suffer intrediction, no more sence spoken, all things Goth and Vandall, till you be summed againe, velvets and scarlets, annointed with gold lace, and cloth of silver turned into Spanish Cottens for a pennance, wits blasted with your bulls, and Tavernes withered, as though the tearme lay at S. Albones.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Gentlemen you have spoken long, and levill, I beseech you take breath a while and here me; you imagine now, by the twirling of your strings, that J am at the last, as also that my friends are flowne like Swallowes after Summer.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: And that I have no more in this poore pannier, to raise me up againe above your rents Vncle.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: All this I doe beleeve.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You have no minde to better me.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Yes cosen, and to that end I come, and once more offer you all that my power is master off.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Amatch then, lay me downe fiftie pound there.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: There it is sir.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: And on it write, that you are pleased to give this, as due unto my merit, without caution of land redeeming, tedious thankes, or thrift hereafter to be hoped for.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: How? Luce layes a suite and letter at the doore.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Without dareing, when you are drunke, to rellish of revilings, to which you are prone in sacke Vncle.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: I thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Come, come away, let the young wanton play a while, away I say sir, let him goe forward with his naked fashion, he will seeke you to morrow; goodly weather, sultrie hot, sultry, how I sweate.

sp.speaker: Vncl.
sp.p: Farewell sir.

sp.speaker: Vnc,
sp.p: Farewell sir. Exeunt Ʋncle and Lance.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Would I sweat too, I am monstrous vext, and cold too; and these are but thinne pumpes to walke the steetes in; cloathes I must get, this fashion will not fadge with me, besides, tis an ill Winter weare, — What art thou? yes, they are cloathes, and rich ones, some foole has left um: and if I should utter — whats this paper here; let these be only worne, by the most noble and deserving Gentleman Vallentine,—dropt out oth' cloudes; I thinke they are full of gold too; well Ile leave my wonder, and be warme agen, in the next house Ile shift. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: VVHy doe you deale thus with him tis unnobly.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Peace cosen peace, you are to tender of him, he must be dealt thus with, he must be cured thus, the violence of his disease Francisco, must not be jested with, tis growne infectious, and now strong corasives most cure him.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Has had a stinger, has eaten off his Cloathes, the next his skinne comes.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: And let it search him to the bones, tis better, twill make him feele it.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Where be his noble friends now? will his fantasticall opinions cloath him, or the learned Art of having nothing feede him.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: It must needes greedely, for all his friends have flung him off, he is naked, and where to skinne himselfe agen, if I know, or can devise how he should get himselfe lodging, his spirit must be bowed, and now we have him, have him at that we hoped for.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Next time we meete him cracking of Nuts, with halfe a clocke about him, for all meanes are cut off, or borrowing sixe pence, to shew his bountie in the pottage Ordidinary.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Which way went he?

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p:
Pox, Why should you aske after him, you have beene trim'd already, let him take his fortune, he spunne it
out himselfe, sir, theres no pitty.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Besides some good to you now from this miserie.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I rise upon his ruines, fie, fie, Vncle, fie honest Lance, those Gentlemen were base people, that could so soone take fire to his destruction.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: You are a foole, you are a foole, a young man.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Morrow Vncle, morrow Francke sweete Francke, and how; and how dee, thinke now, how show matters; morrow Bandogge.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Is this man naked, forsaken of his friends.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Thar't hansome Francke, a pretty Gentleman, ifaith thou lookest well, and yet here may be those that looke as hansome.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Sure he can conjure, and has the devill for his taylor.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: New and rich, tis most impossible he should recover.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Give him this lucke, and fling him into the Sea.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Tis not he, imagination cannot worke this miracle.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Yes, yes, tis he, I will assure you Vncle, the very he, the he your wisdome plaid withall, I thanke you fort, neyed at his nakednes, and made his cold and poverty, your pastime; you see I live, and the best can doe no more Vncle, and though I have no state, I keepe the streetes still; and take my pleasure in the towne, like a poore Gentleman, weare clothes to keepe me warme, poore things they serve me, can make a show too if I list, yes Vncle, and ring a peale in my pockets, ding dong, Vncle, these are mad foolish wayes, but who can helpe um.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: I am amazed.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Ile sell my coppyhold, for since there are such excellent new nothings, why should I labour, is there no fairy haunts him, no rat, nor no old woman.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: You are Vallentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I thinke so, I cannot tell, I have beene cald so, and some say christened, why doe you wonder at me, and swell, as if you had met a sarjeant fasting, did you ever know desert want, yare fooles, a little stoope, there may be to allay him, he would grow too ranke else, a small eclipse, to shaddow him, but out hee must breake, glowingly againe, and with a great luster, looke you Vncle, motion, and Majesty.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: I am confounded.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I am of his faith.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Walke by his carelesse kinsman, and turne againe and walke, and looke thus Vncle, taking some one by the hand, he loves best, leave them to the mercy of the hog market, come Franke, Fortune is now my friend, let me instruct thee.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Good morrow Vncle, I must needes goe with him.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Flay me, and turne me out where none inhabits, within two houres, I shall be thus againe, now wonder on, and laugh at your owne ignorance. Ex. Vall. & Franck.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: I doe beleeve him.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: So doe I, and heartily upon my conscience bury him starke naked, he would rise againe, within two houres imbroidered: sow musterd seedes, and they cannot come up so thicke as his new sattens doe, and clothes of silver, theres no striving.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Let him play a while then, and lets search out what hand: —

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I there the game lyes. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.p: Come lets speake for our selves, we have lodg'd him sure enough, his nakednesse dare not peepe out to crosse us.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: We can have no admittance.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Lets in boldly, and use our best arts, who she daines to favour, we are all content.

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.p: Much good may doe her with him, no civill warres.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: By no meanes, now doe I wonder in what old tod Ivy hee lies whistling for meanes, nor clothes hee has none, nor none will trust him, we have made that side sure, teach him a new wooing.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Say it is his Vncles spite.

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.p: It is all one Gentlemen, 'tas rid us of a faire incumbrance, and makes us looke about to our owne fortunes. Who are these. Enter Isabell and Luce.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Not see this man yet, well, I shall be wiser: but Luce didst ever know a woman melt so, she is finely hurt to hunt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Peace, the three suitors.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I could so titter now and laugh, I was lost Luce, and I must love, I know not what; O Cupid, what pretty gins thou hast to halter woodcockes, and we must into the Countrey in all hast Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: For heavens sake Mistris.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Nay I have done, I must laugh though, but scholler, I shall teach you.

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.p: Tis her sister.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Save you Ladies.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Faire met Gentlemen, you are visiting my sister, I assure my selfe.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: We would faine blesse our eyes.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Behold and welcome, you would see her:

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.p: Tis our businesse.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You shall see her, and you shall talke with her.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Shee will not see um, nor spend a word.

sp.speaker: Isa.
