sp.p: Ile make her fret a thousand, nay now I have found the scab, I will so scratch her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: She cannot endure um.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: She loves um but too dearely, come follow me, Ile bring you toth party Gentlemen, then make your owne conditions.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: She is sicke you know.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ile make her well, or kill her, and take no idle answer, you are fooles then, nor stand off for her state, sheele scorne you all then, but urge her still, and though she fret, still follow her, a widdow must be wonne so.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Shee speakes bravely.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I would faine have a brother in law, I love mens company, and if she call for dinner to avoide you, be sure you stay, follow her into her chamber, if she retire to pray, pray with her, and boldly, like honest lovers.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This will kill her.

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.p: You have showed us one way, do but lend the tother.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I know you stand a thornes, come Ile dispatch you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If you live after this.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I have lost my ayme.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Did you not see um since.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No hang um, hang um.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Nor will you not be seene by um:

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Let um alone Francke, Ile make um their owne justice, and a jerker.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Such base discurteous dogge whelpes.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: I shall dogge um, and double dog um, ere I have done.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Will you goe with me, for I would faine finde out this peece of bountie it was the widdows man, that I am certaine of.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: To what end would you goe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: To give thankes sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Hang giving thankes, hast not thou parts deserves it, it includes to a further will to be beholding, beggers can doe no more at doores, if you will goe there lies your way.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I hope you will goe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No not in ceremony, and to a woman, with mine owne father, were hee living Francke; I would toth Court with beares first, if it be that wench, I thinke it is, for tothers wiser, I would not be so lookt upon, and laught at, so made a ladder for her wit, to climbe upon, for tis the tartest wit in Christendome, I know her well Francke, and have buckled with her, so lickt, and stroakt, fleard upon, and flouted, and showne to Chambermaides, like a strange beast, she had purchased with her penny.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You are a strange man, but doe you thinke it was a woman

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Theres no doubt out, who can be there to doe it else, besides the manner of the circumstances.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Then such courtesies, who ever does um sir, saving your owne wisdome, must be more lookt into, and better answerd, then with deserving slights, or what we ought to have conferd upon us, men may starve else, meanes are not gotton now, with crying out I am a gallant fellow, a good souldier, a man of learning, or fit to be employed, immediate blessings, cease like miracles, and we must grow, by second meanes, I pray goe with me, even as you love me sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I will come to thee, but Francke, I will not stay to heare your fopperies, dispatch those ere I come.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You will not faile me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Some two houres hence expect me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I thanke you, and will looke for you. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Who let me in these puppies, you blinde rascals, you drunken knaves severall.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, Ile let um in presently,—gentlemen,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Spercious you blowne pudding, you bawling rogue.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I bawle as loud as I can, would you have me fetch um upon my backe.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Get um out rascall, out with um, out, I sweate to have um neare me.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I should sweate more to carry um out.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: They are Gentlemen Madam:

sp.speaker: Shor.
sp.p: Shall we get um intoth butterie, and make um drinke.

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.p: Doe any thing, so I be eased.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Now too her sir, feare nothing.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Slip a side boy, I know shee loves um, howsoere shee carries it, and has invited um, my young Mistris told me so.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Away to tables then. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I shall burst with the sport ont.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.p: You are too curious Madam, too full of preparation, we expect it not.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Me thinkes the house is hansome, every place decent, what neede you be so vext.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: We are no strangers.

sp.speaker: Foun,
sp.p: What though we come ere you expected us, doe not we know your entertainements Madam are free, and full at all times.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are merry Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ball.
sp.p: We come to be merry Madam, and very merry, mē live to laugh heartily, and now and then Lady a little of our old plea.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I am busie, and very busie too, will none deliver me.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: There is a time for all, you may be busie, but when your friends come, you have as much power Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: This is a tedious torment.

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.p: How hansomely this title peece of anger shewes upon her, well Madam well, you know not how to grace your selfe.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Nay every thing she does breedes a new sweetnesse.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I must goe up, I must goe up, I have a businesse waites upon me, some wine for the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Nay, weele goe with you, we never saw your chambers yet.

sp.speaker: Jsa.
sp.p: Hold there boyes.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Say I goe to my prayers.

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.p: Weele pray with you, and helpe your meditations.

sp.speaker: Wid,
sp.p: This is boystrous, or say I goe to sleepe, will you goe te sleepe with me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So suddenly before meate will bee dangerous, wee know your dinners ready Lady, you will not sleepe.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Give me my Coach, I will take the aire,

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Weele waite on you, and then your meate after a quickned stomacke.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Let it alone, and call my steward to mee, and bid him
bring his recknings into the Orchard, these unmannerly rude puppies— Exit widdow.

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.p: Weele walke after you and view the pleasure of the place.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Let her not rest, for if you give her breath, sheele scorne and floute you, seeme how she will, this is the way to winne her, be bold and prosper.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Nay if we doe not tire her.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ile teach you to worme me good Lady sister, and peepe into my privacies, to suspect me, Ile torture you, with that you hate most daintily, and when I have done that, laugh at that you love most. Enter Luce.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What have you done, shee chafes and fumes outragiously, and still they persecute her.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Long may they doe so, Ile teach her to declaime against my pitties, why is shee not gone out oth' towne, but gives occasion for men to run mad after her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I shall be hanged.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: This in me had beene high treason, three at a time, and private in her Orchard, I hope sheele cast her reckonings right now. Enter Widdow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well, I shall finde who brought um.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why doe you laugh sister, I feare me tis your tricke, twas neatly done of you, and well becomes your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: What have you done with um.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Lockt um ith Orchard, there Ile make um dance and caper too, before they get their liberty, unmannerly rude puppies.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: They are somewhat saucy, but yet Ile let um out, and once more hound um, why were they not beaten out.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I was about it, but because they came as suiters.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Why did you not answer um.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: They are so impudent they will receive none: More yet, how came these in.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: At the doore Madam.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: It is that face.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Shee sent the money too.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ile leave you, they have some businesse.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay you shall stay sister, they are strangers both to me: how her face alters.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I am sorry he comes now.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I am glad he is here now though. who would you speake with Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: You Lady, or your faire sister there, heres a Gentleman, that has received a benefit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: From whom sir.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: From one of you, as he supposes Madam, your man delivered it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I pray goe forward.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: And of so great a goodnesse, that he dares not, without the tender of his thankes and service, passe by the house.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Which is the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: This Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Whats your name Sir?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: They that know me call me Franscisco Lady, one not so proud to scorne, so timely a benefit, nor so wretched, to hide a gratitude.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It is well bestowed then.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Your faire selfe, or your sister as it seemes, for what desert I dare not know, unlesse a hansome subject for your charities, or aptnesse in your noble wils to doe it, have showred upon my wants, a timely bounty, which makes me rich in thankes, my best inheritance.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I am sorry twas not mine, this is the Gentlewoman-fie doe not blush, goe roundly to the matter, the man is a prettie man.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You have three fine ones.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Then to you deare Lady.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I pray no more Sir, if I may perswade you, your onely aptnesse to doe this is recompence, and more then I expected.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But good Lady.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: And for me further to be acquainted with it, besides the imputation of vaine glory, were greedie thankings of my selfe, I did it not to be more affected to; I did it, and if it happened where I thought it fitted, I have my end, more to enquire is curious in either of us, more then that suspicious:

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But gentle Ladie, twill be necessary.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
About the right way nothing, doe not fright it, being
to pious use and tender sighted, with the blown face of complements, it blasts it had you not come at all, but thought thankes; it had beene too much, twas not to see your person.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A brave dissembling rogue, and how she carries it.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Though I beleeve few handsomer; or heare you, though I affect a good tongue well; or try you, though my yeares desire a friend, that I relieved you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A plaguie cunning queane.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: For so I carryed it, my ends too glorious in mine eies, and bartred the goodnesse I propounded with opinion.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Feare her not Sir.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You cannot catch me sister.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Will you both teach, and tie my tongue up Lady?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Let it suffice you have it, it was never mine, whilst good men wanted it.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: This is a Saint sure.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: And if you be not such a one restore it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: To commend my selfe were more officious, then you thinke my thankes are, to doubt I may be worth your gift a treason, both to mine owne good, and understanding, I know my mind cleare, and though modesty tels me, he that intreates intrudes, yet I must thinke something, and of some season, met with your better taste, this had not beene else.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What ward for that Wench.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Alas it never touched me.

sp.speaker: Fran,
sp.p: Well gentle Ladie, yours is the first money I ever tooke upon a forced ill manners.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: The last of me, if ever you use other.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How may I doe, and your way to be thought a gratefull taker.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Spend it and say nothing, your modestie may deserve more.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O sister, will you barre thankefullnesse?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
Dogges dance for meate, would you have men doe worse, for they can speake, cry out like Woodmongers, good deeds by the hundreds, I did it that my best friend should not know it, wine and vaine glory does as much as I else, if you will force my merit, against my meaning, use it in well bestowing it, in showing it came to be a benefit, and was so; and not examining a woman did it, or to what end, in not beleeving
sometimes your selfe, when drinke and stirring conversation may ripen strange perswasions.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Gentle Lady, J were a base receiver of a curtesie, and you a worse disposer, were my nature unfurnished of these foresights, Ladies honours were ever in my thoughts, unspotted crimes, their good deedes holy temples, where the incense burnes not, to common eyes your feares are vertuous, and so I shall preserve um.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Keepe but this way, and from this place to tell me so, you have paid me; and so J wish you see all fortune. Ex.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: feare not the woman will be thanked, I doe not doubt it, are you so crafty, carry it so precisely, this is to wake my feares, or to abuse mee, I shall looke narrowly, despaire not Gentlemen, there is an houre to catch a woman in, if you be wise, so, I must leave you too; now will I goe laugh at my suitors. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Sir what courage.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: This woman is a founder, and scites statutes to all her benefits.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I never knew yet, so few yeares and so cunning, yet beleeve me she has an itch, but how to make her confesse it, for it is a crafty tit, and playes about you, will not bite home, she would faine, but she dares not; carry your selfe but so discreetely Sir, that want or wantonnesse seeme not to search you, and you shall see her open.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I do love her, and were I rich, would give two thousand pound to wed her wit but one houre, oh tis a dragon, and such a spritely way of pleasure, ha Lance.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Your ha Lance broken once, you would cry, ho, ho, Lance.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Some leaden landed rogue, will have this Wench now, when alls done, some such youth will carry her, and weare her greasie out like stuffe, some dunce that knowes no more but Markets, and admires nothing but a long charge at sises: O the fortunes.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Comfort your selfe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
They are here yet, and a love too, boldly upont, Nay Mistresse, I still told you, how 'would finde your trust, this
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
tis to venture your charitie upon a boy.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Now, whats the matter? stand fast, and like your selfe.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Prethee no more wench.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: What was his want to you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Tis true.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Or misery, or say he had beene ith' Cage, was there no mercy to looke abroad but yours.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I am paid for fooling.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Must every slight companion that can purchase a shew of povertie and beggerly planet fall under your compassion.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Heres a new matter.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Nay you are served but too well, here he staies yet, yet as I live.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How her face alters on me?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Out of a confidence I hope.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I am glad ont.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How doe you gentle Lady?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Much ashamed sir, but first stand further off me y'are infectious to finde such vanitie, nay almost impudence where I beleeve a worth: is this your thankes, the gratitude you were so mad to make me, your trimme councell Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.p: What Lady?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Take your device agen, it will not serve sir, the woman will not bite, you are finely cosened, droppe it no more for shame.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Doe you thinke you are here sir amongst your wastcoateers. your base Wenches that scratch at such occasions; you are deluded; This is a Gentlewoman of a noble house, borne to a better fame than you can build her, and eyes above your pitch.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I doe acknowledge—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Then I beseech you sir, what could see, speake boldly, and speake truely, shame the devill, in my behaviour of such easinesse that you durst venture to doe this.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You amaze me, this Ring is none of mine, nor did I droppe it.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I saw you droppe it sir.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I tooke it up too, still looking when your modesty should misse it, why what a childish part was this?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: J vow.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
Vow me no vowes, he that dares doe this, has bred himselfe to boldnesse, to forsweare too; there take your gugaw you are too much pampered, and I repent my part, as
you grow older grow wiser if you can, and so farewell sir.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Grow wiser if you can, shee has put it to you, tis a rich Ring, did you droppe it?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Never, nere see it afore Lance.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Thereby hangs a taile then: what slight shee makes to catch her selfe, looke up sir, you cannot lose her if you would, how daintily she flies upon the lure, and cunningly she makes her stoppes, whistle and she'le come to you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I would I were so happie.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Maids are clockes, the greatest wheele they show, goes slowest to us, and makes hang on tedious hopes the lesser, which are concealed being often oyl'd with wishes flee like desires, and never leave that motion, till the tongue strikes; she is flesh, blood, and marrow, young as her purpose, and soft as pitty; no Monument to worship, but a mould to make men in, a neate one, and I know how ere she appeares now, which is neare enough, you are starke blinde if you hit not soone at night; shee would venture fortie pounds more but to feele a flea in your shape bite her: drop no more Rings forsooth, this was the prettiest thing to know her heart by.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Thou putst me in much comfort.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Put your selfe in good comfort, if shee doe not point you out the way, droppe no more rings, she'le droppe her selfe into you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I wonder my brother comes not.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Let him alone, and feede your selfe on your owne fortunes; come be frolicke, and lets be monstrous wise and full of councell, droppe no more Ringes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: If you will needes be fool sh you must be used so: who sent for you? who entertained you Gentlemen? who bid you welcome hether? you came crowding, and impudently bold; presse on my patience, as if I kept a house for all Companions, and of all sorts; will have you wills, will 'vexe me and force my liking from you, I never owed you.

sp.speaker: Fount.
sp.p: For all this we will dine with you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And for all this will have a better answer from you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
You shall never, neither have a answer nor dinner,
unlesse you use me with a more staid respect, and stay your time too. Enter Isabella, Shorthose, Roger, Humphrey, Ralph, with dishes of meate.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Forward with the meate now.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Come gentlemen march fairely.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Roger, you are a weake Servingman, your white broath runnes from you; fie, how I sweate under this pile of Beefe; an Elephant can doe more, oh for such a backe now, and in these times, what might a man arrive at; Goose grase you up, and Woodcocke march behinde thee, I am almost foundred.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Who bid you bring the meate yet? away you knaves, J will not dine these two houres, how am I vext and chafed; goe carry it backe and tell the Cooke, hee's an arrant Rascall, to send before I called.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Faces about Gentlemen, beate a mournefull march then, and give some supporters, or esse I perish—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: It does me much good to see her chafe thus.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Wee can stay Madame, and will stay and dwell here, tis good Ayre.

sp.speaker: Fonn.
sp.p: I know you have beds enough, and meate you never want.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You want a little.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We dare to pretend on, since you are curlish, wee'le give you physicke, you must purge this anger, it burnes you and decaies you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: If I had you out once I would be at charge of a percullis for you. Enter Vallantine.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Good morrow noble Lady.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Good morrow sir, how sweetly now he lookes, and how full manly, what slaves was these to use him so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I come to looke a young man I call brother.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Such a one was here sir, as I remember your owne brother, but gone almost an houre agoe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: God e'n then.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You must not so soone sir, here be some Gentlemen, it may be you are acquainted with um.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Will nothing make him miserable?

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.p: How glorious!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It is the very he, does it faine fortunes, or has hee a familliar.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: How doggedly he lookes too.

sp.speaker: Foun.
sp.p: I am beyond my faith, pray lets be going.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Where are these Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Yes I know um and will be more famillier.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Morrow Maddam.

sp.speaker: Wid,
sp.p: Nay stay and dine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You shall stay till I talke with you, and not dine neither, but fastingly my fury, you thinke you have undone me, thinke so still, and swallow that beleefe, till you be company for Court-hand Clarkes, and starved Atturneyes, till you breake in at playes like Prentises for three a groat, and cracke nuts with the sc ollers in penny Roomes agen, and fight for Apples, till you returne to what I found you, people betrai'd into the hands of Fencers, Challengers, Toothdrawers bills, and tedious Proclamations in Meale-markets, with throngings to see Cutpurses: stirre not, but heare, and marke, Ile cut your throates else, till Waterworkes, and rumours of new Rivers rid you againe and runne you into questions who built Theamea, till you runne mad for Lotteries, and stand there with your tables to gleane the golden sentenses, and cite um secretly to Servingmen for sound Essayes, till Tavernes allow you but a Towell roome to tipple in wine that the Bell hath gone for twice, and glasses that looke like broken promises, tied up with wicker protestations, English Tobacco with halfe pipes, nor in halfe a yeare once burnt, and Bisket that Bawdes have rubb'd their gummes upon like Curralls to bring the marke againe; tell these houre rascalls so, this most fatall houre will come againe, thinke I sit downe the looser.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Will you stay Gentlemen, a peece of beefe and a cold Capon, thats all, you know you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: That was cast to abuse us.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Steale off, the devill is in his anger.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay I am sure you will not leave me so discurteously now I have provided for you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
What doe you heare? why doe vexe a woman of her goodnesse, her state and worth; can you bring a faire certificate
that you deserve to be her footemen; husbands, you puppies, husbands for Whores and Bawdes, away you windsuckers; doe not looke bigge, nor prate, nor stay, nor grumble, and when you are gone seeme to laugh at my fury, and slight this Lady, I shall heare, and know this: and though I am not bound to fight for women, as farre as they are good I dare preserve um: be not too bold, for if you be Ile swinge you, Ile swinge you monstrousty without all pitty, your honours now goe, avoide me mainely. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well sir, you have delivered me, I thanke you, and with your noblenesse prevented danger their tongues might utter, will all goe and eate sir.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: No, no, I dare not trust my selfe with women, goe to your meate, eate little, take lesse ease, and tie your body to a daily labour, you may live honestly, and so I thank you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well goe thy wayes, thou art a noble fellow, and some meanes I must worke to have thee know it. Exit.

div.head: Scaen. 1.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: MOst certaine tis, her hands that hold him up, and her sister relieves Franke.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I am glad to heare it: but wherefore doe they not pursue this fortune to some faire end?

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: The women are too craftie, Ʋellentine too coy, and Franke too bashfull, had any wise man hold of such a blessing, they would strick it out oth' flint but they would forme it. Enter Widdow and Shorthose.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: The Widdow sure, why does she stirre so earely.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Tis strange, I cannot force him to understand mee, and make a benefit, of what J would bring him, tell my sister ile use any devotions at home this morning, shee may if shee please goe to Church.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Hay ho.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And doe you waite upon her with a torch sir?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Hay ho.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You lasie knave.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Here is such a tincle tanklings that we can nerelie quiet, and sleepe our prayers out, Ralph pray emptie my right shooe that you made your Chamberpot, and burne a little Rosemary int, I must waite upon my Lady. This morning Prayer has brought me into a consumption, I have nothing left but flesh and bones about me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You drousie slave, nothing but sleepe and swilling.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Had you beene bitten with bandogge fleaes, as I have beene, and haunted with the night Mare.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: With an Alepot.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: You would have little list to morning Prayers, pray take my fellow Ralph, hee has a Psalme booke, I am an ingrum man.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Get you ready quickly, and when she is ready waite upon her hansomely; no more, be gone.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: If I doe snore my part out— Exit Short.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Now to our purposes.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Good morrow Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Good morrow Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Good joy and fortune.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: These are good things, and worth my thankes, I thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Much joy I hope you'le finde, we came to gratulate, your new knit marriage band.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Hes a Gentleman although he be my kinsman, my faire Neece.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Neece Sir?

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Yes Lady, now I may say so, tis no shame to you, I say a Gentleman, and winking at some light fancies, which you most happily may affect him for, as bravely carried, as nobly bred and managed.

sp.speaker: Wid,
sp.p: Whats all this, I understand you not, what Neece, what marriage knot.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Ile tell plainely, you are my Neece, and Vallentine the Gentleman has made you so by marriage.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Marriage?

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Yes Lady, and twas a noble and a vertuous part, to take a falling man to your protection, and bay him up againe to all his glories.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: The men are mad.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: What though he wanted these outward things, that flie away like shadowes; was not his minde a full one, and a brave one, you have wealth enough to give him glosse, and outside; and he wit enough to give way to love a Lady.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: I ever thought he would doe well.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Nay, I knew how ever he wheel'd about like a loose Cabine, he would charge home at length, like a brave Gentleman, heavens blessing a your heart Lady, wee are so bound to honour you, in all your service so devoted to you.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Doe not looke so strange Widdow it must be knowne, better a generall joy; no stirring here yet, come, come you cannot hide um.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray be not impudent, these are the finest toyes, belike I am married then.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You are in a miserable estate in the worlds account else, I would not for your wealth it come to doubting.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And I am great with child?

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: No; great they say not, but tis a full opinion you are with childe, and great joy among the Gentlemen, your husband hath bestirred himselfe fairely.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Alas, we know his private houres of entrance, how long, and when he staied, could name the bed too where hee paid downe his first fruits.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I shall beleeve anon.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: And we consider for some private reasons, you would have it private, yet take your owne pleasure; and so good morrow my best Neece, my sweetest.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No, no, pray stay.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: I know you would be with him, love him, and love him well.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You'le finde him noble, this may beget—

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: It must needes work upon her. Exit Vnc. & Mer.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
These are fine bobes I faith, married, and with child too, how long has this beene I trow? they seeme grave fellowes,
they should not come to flout; married, and bedded, the world take notice too, where lies this May game, I could be vext extreamely now, and raile too, but tis to no end, though I itch little, must J be scratcht I know not how, who waites there?

sp.speaker: Hum,
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Make ready my Coach quickly, and waite you onely, and harke you sir, be secret and speedy, enquire out where he lies.

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.p: I shall doe it Madam. Exit

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Married, and got with child in a dreame, tis fine ifaith, sure he that did this, would doe better waking. Exit

div.stage: Enter Vallentine, Fran. Lance, and a boy with a torch.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Hold thy Torch hansomely, how dost thou Francke, Peter Bassell, beare up.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You have fryed me soundly, Sacke doe you call this drinke.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: A shrewd dogge Francke, will bite abundantly.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Now could I fight, and fight with thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: With me thou man of Memphis.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: But that thou art mine owne naturall Master, yet my sackes saies thou art no man, thou art a Pagan, and pawnest thy land, which a noble cause.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No armes, no armes, good Lancelet, deare Lance, no fighting here, we will have Lands boy, Livings, and Titles, thou shalt be a Viceroy, hang fighting, hang tis out of fashion

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I would faine labour you into your lands againe, goe too, it is behoovefull.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Fie Lance, fie.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I must beate some body, and why not my Master, before stranger, charity and beating begins at home.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Come thou shalt beate me.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I will not be compeld, and you were two Masters, I scorne the motion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Wilt thou sleepe.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I scorne sleepe.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Wilt thou goe eate.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p:
I scorne meate, I come for compering, I come to waite
upon my charge discreetely, for looke you if you will not take your Morgage againe, here doe I lie Saint George, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And here doe I St. George, bestride the Dragon, thus with my Lance.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I sting, I sting with my taile.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Doe you so, doe you so Sir, I shall taile you presently.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: By no meanes doe not hurt him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Take his Nellson, and now rise, thou maiden Knight of Malligo, lace on thy helmet of inchanted sacke, and charge againe.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I play no more, you abuse me, will you goe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ile bid you good morrow Brother, for sleepe I cannot I have a thousand fancies:

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Now thou art arived, goe bravely to the matter, and doe something of worth Francke.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: You shall heare from us. Exit Lance and Frank.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: This rogue, if he had beene sober, sure had beaten me, is the most tettish knave.

div.stage: Enter Ʋncle and Merchant: May with a torch.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Tis he.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Good morrow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why sir good morrow to you too, and you be so lusty

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: You have made your brother a fine man, we met him.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: I made him a fine Gentleman, he was a foole before, brought up amongst the midst of small beere Brue-houses, what would you have with me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I come to tell you, your latest houre is come.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Are you my sentence.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: The sentence of your state.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Let it be hangd then, and let it be hangd hie enough, I may not see it.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: A gratious resolution.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What would you else with me, will you goe drinke, and let the world slide Vncle, ha, ha, ha, boyes, drinke sacke like whey boyes.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Have you no feeling sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Come hither Merchant: Make me a supper, thou most
reverent Land catcher, a supper of forty pound.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: What then sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Then bring thy wife along, and thy faire sisters, thy neighbours and their wives, and all their trinkets, let me have forty trumpets, and such wine, weele laugh at all the miseries of morgage, and then in state Ile render thee an answer.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: What say to this.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc,
sp.p: I dare not say nor thinke neither.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Will you redeeme your state, speake to the point sir.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Not, not if it were mine heire in the Turkes gallies.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Then I must take an order.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Take a thousand, J will not keepe it, not thou shalt not have it, because thou camest ith nick, thou shalt not have it, goe take possession, and be sure you hold it, hold fast with both hands, for there be those hounds uncoupled, will ring you such a knell, goe downe in glory, and march upon my Land, and cry alls mine, cry as the devil did, and be the devill, marke what an eccho followes, build fine Marchpanes, to entertaine Sir Silkeworme and his Lady, and pull the Chappell downe, to raise a Chamber for Mistris Silver in, to lay her belly in, marke what an Earthquake comes, then foolish Merchant my tennants are no subjects, they obey nothing, and they are people too, never Christned, they know no law, nor conscience, theile devoure thee: and thou mortall the stople, theile confound thee, within three dayes; no bit nor memory of what thou wert, no not the wart upon thy nose there, shall be ere heard of more, goe take possession, and bring thy children downe, to rost like rabbits, they love young toasts, and butter, Bowbell suckers; as they love mischiefe, and hate law, they are Canibals: bring downe thy kindred too, that be not fruitfull, there be those Mandrakes, that will mollifie um, goe take possession, Ile goe to my Chamber, afore boy goe. Exeu.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Hees mad sure.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Hees halfe drunke sure, and yet I like this unwillingnesse to loose it this looking backe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yes if he did it hansomely, but hees so harsh, & strange

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Beleeve it tis his drinke sir, and I am glad his drinke has thrust it out.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Cannibals; if ever I come to view his regements, if faire termes may be had.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Hee tels you true sir; They are a bunch of the most boystrous rascalls disorder ever made, let um be mad once, the power of the whole Country cannot coole um, be patient but a while.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: As long as you will sir, before I buy a bargaine of such runts, Ile buy a Colledge for Beares, and live among um.

div.stage: Enter Franscisco, Lance, boy with a torch.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How dost thou now.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Better then I was, and straighter, but my heads a hogshead still, it rowles and tumbles.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Thou wert cruelly paid.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I may live to requite it, put a snaffle of sacke in my mouth, and then ride me very well.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Twas all but sport, Ile tell thee what I meane now, I meane to see this wench.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Where a devill is shee, and there were two, 'tweare better.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Dost thou heare the bell ring.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Then shee comes to prayers, earely each morning thether: Now if I could but meete her, for I am of another mettle now.

div.stage: Enter Isabell, and Shorthose with a Torch.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: What lights yond.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ha, tis a light, take her by the hand and Court her.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Take her below the girdle, youle never speed else, it comes on this way still, oh that I had but such an opportunity in a saw pit, how it comes on, comes on, tis here.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Tis she, fortune I kisse thy hand—good morrow Lady.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: What voyce is that sirrha, doe you sleepe as you goe, tis he, I am glad ont, why Shorthose.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, I was dreamt, I was going to Church.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Shee sees you as plaine as I doe.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Hold thy Torch up.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p:
Heres nothing but a stall, and a Butchers dogge a
sleepe int, where did you see the voyce.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Shee lookes still angry.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: To her and meet sir.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Here, here.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes Lady, never blesse your selfe, I am but a man, and like an honest man, now I will thanke you—

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: What do you meane, who sent for you, who desired you

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Shall I put out the Torch forsooth.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Can I not goe about my private meditations, hay, but such companions as you must ruffle me, you had best got with me sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Twas my purpose.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Why what an impudence is this, you had best, being so neare the Church, provide a Priest, and perswade me to marry you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: It was my meaning, and such a husband, so loving, and so carefull, my youth, and all my fortunes shall arrive at — Harke you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Tis strange you should be thus unmannerly, turne home againe sirrah, you had best now force my man to leade your way.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Yes marry shall a Lady, forward my friend.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: This is a pretty Riot, it may grow to a rape.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Doe you like that better, I can ravish you an hundred times, and never hurt you.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I see nothing, I am asleepe still, when you have done tell me, and then Ile wake Mistris.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Are you in earnest Sir, doe you long to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes by my troth Lady in these faire tresses.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Shall I call out for helpe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No by no meanes, that were a weake tricke Lady, Ile kisse and stoppe your mouth.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Youle answer all these.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A thousand kisses more.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I was never abused thus, you had best give out too, that you found me willing, and say I doted on you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Thats knowne already, and no man living shall now carry you from me.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: This is fine ifaith.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: It shall be tenne times finer.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Well seeing you are so valiant, keepe your way, I will to Church.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And I will waite upon you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
And it is most likely theres a Priest, if you dare ven •…
ter as you professe, I would wish you looke about you, to doe these rude trickes, for you know their recompences, and trust not to my mercy.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But I will Lady.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: For Ile so handle you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Thats it I looke for.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Afore thou dreame.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Have you done.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Goe on sir, and follow if you dare.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: If I doe not hang me.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Tis all thine owne boy, an 'twere a million, god a mercy Sacke, when would small Beere have done this. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Whose that that knockes and bounces, what a devill ailes you, is hell broke loose, or doe you keepe an Iron mill.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Tis a Gentlewoman sir that must needs speak with you.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: A Gentlewoman, what Gentlewoman, what have I to doe with Gentlewomen?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: She will not be answerd Sir.

sp.speaker: Ʋal
sp.p: Fling up the bed and let her in, Ile try how gentle she is— Exit Servant. This sacke has fild my head so full of bables, I am almost mad; what Gentlewoman should this be, I hope she has brought me no butter print along with her to lay to my charge, if she have tis all one, Ile forsweare it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O your a noble gallant, send of your servant pray.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Shee will not ravish mee, by this light shee lookes as sharpe set as a Sparrow hawke, what wouldst thou woman.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O you have used me kindely, and like a Gentleman, this tis to trust to you.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Trust to me, for what.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Because I said in jeast once, you were a hansome man, one I could like well, and fooling, made you beleeve I loved you, and might be brought to marry.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The Widdow is drunke too.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You out of this which is a fine discretion, give out the matters done, you have wonne and wed mee, and that you have put fairely for an heire too, these are fine rumours to advance my credit; ith name of mischiefe what did you meane.

sp.speaker: Ʋal,
sp.p: That you loved me, and that you might be brought to marry me, why, what a devill doe you meane Widdow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Twas a fine tricke too, to tell the world though you had enjoyed your first wish, you wished the wealth you aimed at; that I was poore, which is most true, I am, have sold my Lands because I love not those vexations, yet for mine honors sake, if you must be prating, and for my credits sake in the Towne.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I tell thee Widdow, I like thee ten times better, now thou hast no Lands, for now thy hopes and cares, lye on thy husband, if ere thou marryest more.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Have not you married me, and for this maine cause, now as you report it, to be your Nurse.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: My Nurse, why what am I growne too, give me the glasse, my Nurse.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You nere said truer, I must confesse I did a little favour you, and with some labour, might have beene perswaded, but when I found I must bee hourely troubled, with making brawthes, and dawbing your decaies with swadling, and with stitching up your ruines, for the world so reports.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Doe not provoke me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And halfe an eye may see.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Doe not provoke me, the worlds a lying world, and thou shalt finde it, have a good heart, and take a strong faith to thee, and marke what followes, my Nurse, yes, you shall rocke me: Widdow Ile keepe you waking.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are disposed sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes marry am I Widdow, and you shall feele it, nay and they touch my freehold, I am a Tiger.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I thinke so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Come.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Whether.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Any whether. Sings.

lg.l: The fits upon me now, the fits upon me now,
Come quickely gentle Lady, the fits upon me now,
The world shall know they are fooles,
And so shalt thou doe too,
Let the Cobler meddle with his tooles,

sp.p: Take me quickly while I am in this vaine, away with me, for if I have but two houres to consider, all the Widdowes in the world cannot recover me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: If you will, goe with me sir.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Yes marry will I, but tis in anger yet, and J will marry thee, doe not crosse me; yes, and J will lie with thee, and get a whole bundle of babies, and I will kisse thee, stand still and kisse me hansomely, but do not provoke me, stirre neither hand nor foote, for I am dangerous, I drunk sacke yesternight, doe not allure me: Thou art no widdow of this world, come in pitty, and in spite Ile marry thee, not a word more, and J may be brought to love thee. Exeunt

div.stage: Enter Merchant and Vncle at severall doores.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Well met agen, and what good newes yet.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Faith nothing.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No fruites of what we sowed.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: Nothing I heare of.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No turning in this tide yet.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Tis all flood, and till that fall away, theres no expecting.

div.stage: Enter Fran. Jsab. Lance. Shorthose, a torch.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Is not this his younger brother.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: With a Gentlewoman the Widdowes sister, as I live he smiles, he has got good hold, why well said Francke ifaith, lets stay and marke.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Well you are the prettiest youth, and so you have handled me, thinke you ha me sure.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: As sure as wedlocke.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You had best lye with me too.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes indeed will I, and get such blacke ey'd boyes.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: God a mercy Francke.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: This is a merry world, poore simple Gentlewomen that thinke no harme, cannot walke about their businesse, but they must be catcht up I know not how.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ile tell you, and Ile instruct you too, have I caught you Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Isa,
sp.p: Well, and it were not for pure pitty, I would give you the slip yet, but being as it is.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: It shall be better.

div.stage: Enter Vallentine, Widdow, and Ralph with a Torch.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: My sister as I live, your brother with her, sure I thinke you are the Kings takers.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Now it workes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay you shall know I am a man.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I thinke so.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: And such proofe you shall have.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I pray speake softly.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ile speake it out Widdow, yes and you shall confesse too, I am no nurse child, I went for a man, a good one, if you can beate me out oth' pit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I did but jest with you.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Ile handle you in earnest, and so handle you: Nay when my credit cals.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Are you mad.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: I am mad, I am mad.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Good morrow Sir, I like your preparation.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Thou hast beene at it Francke.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes faith, tis done sir,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: A long with me then, never hang an arse Widdow.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Tis to no purpose sister.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well said blackebrowes, advance your Torches Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Yes, yes sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And keepe your ranckes.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Lance carry this before him.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Carry it in state.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What are you Musitians, I know your comming, and what are those behinde you.

sp.speaker: Musi.
sp.p: Gentlemen that sent us to give the Lady, a good morrow.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: O I know them, come boy sing the song I taught you,
And sing it iustily, come forward Gentlemen, your welcome,
Welcome, now we are all friends goe get the Priest ready,
And let him not be long, we have much businesse:
Come Francke rejoyce with me, thou hast got the start boy,
But ile so tumble after, come my friends leade,
Lead chearefully, and let your fiddles ring boyes,
My follies and my fancies have an end here,
Display the morgage Lance, Merchant ile pay you,
And every thing shall be in joynt agen.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: A fore, afore.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Wit without Money, sometimes gives the blow.
